awd_titl_txt: WIDE ANALYSIS OF LOW-ENERGY PLASMONICALLY-POWERED CASCADED DYNAMICS IN LIQUIDS
awd_abstract_narration:
Nontechnical description: Surface plasmons are collective oscillations of electrons at the interface between a metal and an insulator. In the physical, biomedical, and environmental sciences, metal nanomaterials are well-known to absorb and concentrate light through plasmonic effects. The energy from surface plasmons has been shown to power a variety of novel chemical, thermal, electrical and mechanical phenomena. This project addresses recent observations of plasmonic interactions in liquid-dispersed metal nanoparticles onto which weak magnetic fields are applied. Results from this study explain how the energy of plasmons is transferred to their surrounding environment, and thus relate to profound environmental, biological, and physiological effects. Interdisciplinary and data-intensive research activities provide versatile technical training for future science professionals. The principal investigator is also actively engaged in teaching in New York City public high school College Now! programs, mentoring high school students who have successfully advanced to the Intel International Science and Engineering Fair, and organizing a new discussion-centered Research Conference in Hong Kong, with the aim of accelerating and disseminating knowledge of plasmon energy transfer.

Technical description: The project is centered on understanding the longer-lived light-induced changes in plasmonically-absorbing nanofluids, particularly those that result from the simultaneous illumination of low-intensity light and static magnetic fields. The formation of vapor around nanoparticles is studied, and the dynamics of the vapor-encased nanoparticles are imaged, enabling transformative analytical models of the multi-phase hydrodynamics. The dovetailed study of the near-field and far-field behaviors is essential for designing future optical probes and interpreting the optical response of nanofluids.  The principal investigator also characterizes the novel thermophoretic, thermoelectric, and electrokinetic behavior of bulk nanofluids by analyzing the near-field behavior of plasmonic 2D substrates surrounded by liquids. The wide analysis and approach may pinpoint elusive and anomalous behaviors associated with plasmons to explain the observed critical nucleation of dissolved gasses in liquids on plasmonic surfaces, which is currently not understood.

por.por_cntn:
The cost of clean water is an issue of critical global importance in the near foreseeable future.

In this NSF project, we studied the response of light on nanosized structures for environmental water-related applications. Interdisciplinary and data-intensive research activities provided technical, educational, and entrepreneurial training, which were particularly valuable during and through the COVID pandemic, 2020-2022.

In our NSF project and with a team of mostly Master's-level researchers, we provided some of the first experimental results of nonphotothermal solar desalination, or the accelerated separation of salt and water by the illumination of light by targeting salt-water bonds instead of heating (or having light absorbed by) water-water bonds. Our research results are a milestone because most solar harvesting technologies produce thermal island or net heating effects on earth. (In other words, while solar energy in itself is abundant and 'renewable', it can contribute to net heating effects, which are not desirable.)

To demonstrate nonphotothermal desalination, we combined the capillary response of hard, hydrophilic porous white ceramics with knowledge of general interfacial evaporative cooling processes. With some technical jargon: we exploited the aluminum nitride material bandgap energy that overlaps with the binding energy of salt and water. When light was absorbed by a material with a bandgap that overlapped with the salt-water binding energy, saltwater evaporated ten times more readily.

Beyond water treatment, our work may have other important applications. For example, in hot and dry climates, evaporative or "swamp" coolers are technologically advantageous (capable of producing temperature differences as large as 25C with a small fan, for example).  However, these water-based technologies are not feasible if there is also a water shortage or drought. Therefore, our research intellectual advances may enable cooling in hot climates without the use of clean water. 


Beyond research, the PI's group has also participated in diverse training and public outreach activities, enabled by NSF. Some activities have been carefully refined over many years: for example, a Communication Physics module started in 2005 with Jim Overhiser and the NSF-funded Cornell Institute of Physics Teachers when the PI was a PhD student; from 2010 to 2018, the NSF-funded PI created and demonstrated similar units across New York City. At UC Riverside, the PI renamed the project “Audio-Via-Optics,” and a year ago, the PI's research group set up an interactive booth using pre-built transceivers as part of Riverside’s 2023 Long Night of Art and Innovation. 

Current efforts through NSF have provided resources for a high-school outreach project that the PI and students have developed with guidance from UC Riverside’s Mathematics, Engineering and Science Achievement (MESA) Program. The PI group has put together 50 transceiver kits for this project. This highly interactive project will not only give students an introduction to the practice of building electronic circuits, but it will also teach them higher-level concepts from optical physics and communications theory. 

This Audio-Via-Optics project has been evolving due in large part to the efforts of the PI's former NSF-funded students and volunteers. This group has established a robust collaboration with MESA’s staff, who are not only advising us on lesson design, but will also facilitate connections to local high schools. As we teach students, we will also be training local teachers, who will then be able to run the short (5-session) course without our assistance. This 5-session module may be disseminated by UC Riverside student teachers to high school teachers and at high-school extracurricular programs across Southern California. As the team gets feedback on the module, it will be refined in ways that make it easier for teachers to increase their students’ interest in engineering.
